Comment: If your plan is to ADD a dedicated lane for buses, there is some logic. If it's "block off an existing lane for buses & people will leave their car & climb aboard", I think you will find that has been tried elsewhere, resulting in more congestion & angry commuters.

Your plan that more buses will get people out of their cars is based on a number of assumptions- that existing buses are viewed as ideal but too full, buses can get people exactly where they need to be in approximately the same time as driving, & people don't need to drop/ retrieve kids at daycare/school, visit elderly relatives en route, travel to other work sites/client locations during the day, or the many other valid reasons responsibilities require ready access to transportation for specific locations & timing transit planners can't accommodate.

Assuming transit lines will get most people to work without transfers & significant time, & all they need a car for is commuting, applies to fewer folks than you think.

Comment: "A basic income would allow the neo-liberal agenda to remain intact." 
Actually, neo-liberalism has little to do with it. Even Donald Trump's notional nationalist (America First!) capitalism has the same problem.
Most people get to share in the output of society through being paid for a job. But advances in technology mean that enterprises need fewer people for the same output. People don't just disappear when they are not needed. Unless we find a way to include them, they become a problem.  
Already, we have a society that provides a good and secure life for only about 20% of the population. Life for the rest is increasingly a scramble of precarious low-paid employment, causing them great difficulty in housing and caring for themselves. 
Basic Income might have its own alienating effects, but would it be any worse than the alienation of traditional waged work? Reguly fails to even outline a better vision for an inclusive economy.

Comment: You want politics out of your sporting events?  Then let's stop playing the anthem at them.  There are so, so many more practical ways to honor the nation and those who served. 

Once upon a time some organ player at some long-forgotten minor league baseball game played the Star Spangled Banner to hype up the home fans.  Decades later it's morphed into a political statement.  It's a tradition that has run its course.

We don't play football during Veteran's ceremonies.  Baseball games don't break out during presidential caucuses.  Sports and politics don't mix.  Unfortunately, the anthem has become just another political tool.

Genie is out of the bottle, people.  Can't put this one back.

Comment: That's what I mean about protecting assets. You bet that you will need to replace your car/house/knee; the insurance carrier is betting you won't. You'll likely pay more in premiums than you'll gain. That makes it a sucker's bet, similar to betting $5 a week on the lottery for 30 years. You might win millions; you'll definitely just spend $7,800.

However, although the odds are against it, you're better off spending a little now than a bunch later should you wreck your car/house/knee. That makes it a prudent bet because you'll keep your assets, especially if you wreck someone else's car/house/knee. It's still a cash loser in the long term.

But, yes, I'd much prefer to sock away cash now (better, invest it so it grows while you're not using it) for such an eventuality. Most of us can't quickly enough save $400,000 to rebuild the house, so we give State Farm a few hundred a month instead. State Farm gets the immediate benefit of that cash, not you.

Comment: As currently practiced, part of the firefighting industry appears to be a hugely expensive subset of the timber industry, gorged with a huge fleet of stand-by bulldozers, excavators, heavy trucks, and even a logging helicopter air force. In spite of all this industry heavy metal, it is often the fuel clearing and back firing ground crews along with the changing weather that have the greatest effect on reducing fires.

There should be an intelligent audit of fire fighting expenditures versus effectiveness before throwing yet more millions into the many inevitable blazes.

To reduce risk to public personnel attempting to save private forest dwellings, zoning and building codes should require defensive locations, site preparation, and access and construction standards for future forest homes. Folks wishing to build in the forest should sign a disclaimer acknowledging the risk and responsibility of living in the forest and relieving the public of any forest fire related liability.

Comment: I have so much respect for Michael from the few times I met him and listened to his teaching. I am so sad that he was not able to share his mental health struggle more broadly before his passing and to experience support and compassion from others. My guess is much of that had to do with some deep shame from existing stigma about mental illness and using prescription medications to help treat it. I wonder if he feared the risk of losing credibility as a teacher with students saying, " if his spiritual practices are insufficient to help him be free of his mental health symptoms, how will he help me?" There is a dogma in some spiritual traditions that looks down on practitioners and teachers who may choose to rely on prescribed medications to help with severe mental health issues. The truth in my experience, is that dealing with a mental illness requires help from all angles, there is no one formula. Spiritual practice and medication can go together; let us leave the shame behind.

Comment: If you plan to travel a thousand miles in a few hours and arrive at the last minute, expect to occasionally fail. This story depicts not the travails of weather so much as the problems with poor planning. Air travel is notorious for failing to operate perfectly in imperfect winter weather; this shouldn't be news to anyone.

Of course that's not a problem I ever encounter. When I wish to travel between Oregon and California (or Washington) and the roads are too icy to ride a bike, I simply walk to the train station and get on the Coast Starlight (or Cascades, if heading north). While the trip takes longer than flying, it's nice and comfy in my sleeper car and I have everything I need even if the train is delayed, including food, drinks and a shower.

Comment: Actually it isn't a basic wildlife biology principle. Indeed, if you look at classic long term predator-prey studies, ergo Errington's mink-muskrat study, Keith's lynx-snowshoe hare study, or Allen/Mech's wolf-moose study, you will see that it was prey population level that controlled predator population level, not vice versa. Prey populations in most cases tend to be controlled by habitat quality, not predators. Indeed, as you well know modern wildlife management is based on habitat quality improvement to increase carrying capacity, NOT on predator control. Again, please post peer reviewed research links if you have good evidence to the contrary. Sadly, perception dies hard.

Comment: There's undeniably some truth to that, but your claim about it being a 95% decline isn't supported by that link, and is completely refuted by the current data. http://monarchwatch.org/blog/uploads/2016/02/monarch-population-figure-monarchwatch-2016.png

As the author mentions, year-to-year changes can vary significantly due to factors like the weather, which is why they've provided averages. It's much more accurate to say that monarch populations have declined 43%. Mind you, I'm not saying that that's somehow "acceptable", but at this point herbicide-tolerant crops have essentially reached saturation. If there is further habitat loss, it has to be due to some other factor.

It's also worth pointing out the opposite side of the issue. The adoption of herbicide-tolerant crops has reduced the use of tilling as a weed-control method. That, in turn, reduces erosion which can be extremely harmful to the environment.

Comment: Be aware this issue is froth with confusion, complexity and misinformation. If you think Indian status is complicated on mainland Canada, it is more so on the Island of Newfoundland. When NL joined Canada it was supposed Island Mi'kmaq would fall under the Indian Act. Turns out the feds were already planning to wean Canada's aboriginals off government subsidies and so St. Laurent denied federal responsibility. NL had neither the wherewithal nor inclination to fill in for the feds and so NL's innu languished in no-man's land for decades. The province was also convinced its Mi'kmaq were not aboriginal, at least not to NL - that their arrival post-dated the European presence there (and hence with no stronger land claim than any other settler). The criteria for Qalipu status is more narrow than the national model; they must have a current and substantial connection to native communities on the Island. And that, it turns out, accounts for the vast majority of the rejections. 

Clear as mud?

Comment: But maintaining healthy stem cells may not be about growth at all.

Stem cells actually do not divide very much. Their offspring cells do, but the stem cells, at the top of the chain, do not.

The concern is more along the lines of losing them over time, of keeping them alive.

The anti-oxidants in blueberries, for example, are not thought so much to be stimulating cell growth, rather the idea is that their molecules help soak up damaging free radicals that otherwise damage DNA and cell membranes.

Comment: Those who separate humans into groups - those that like cats and those that don't - do nothing but create divisiveness. Humans are more complex than that.  I am founder and director of a cat shelter for 15 years and have always had a great fondness for cats, both domestic and wild. Experiencing the sheer numbers of domestic ferals free-roaming, living half-lives between domestic and wild, living and dying horribly and being shunned by some as vermin made me want to help them directly. Through my shelter we provide a safe haven, health care, compassion and rehome them - indoors. Those that cannot we make the decision to euthanize. I won't practice TNR (something I tried) because I see the misery it causes to the cats and to wildlife that they hunt, maim and kill. Many people who we helped with removing stray/feral cats from their property are amazed at the wildlife that they now see in their yards, and are grateful for it. And many of these same people have beloved indoor cats.

Comment: "A main driver behind the law's passage was research that showed two-thirds of people released from prison in Alaska went back in within three years."

Not having "gone back into prison" is not a useful measure of recidivism by any definition. Recidivism refers to committing further crimes. If a released prisoner commits another crime, particularly one substantially related to the one(s) they were previously convicted of, they are a recidivist. That they may somehow escape prison time is irrelevant. Heck, for most simply being in a position where there is sufficient probable cause for an -arrest- for a similar offense is evidence they haven't changed their life and lifestyle to any significant degree.

Comment: CETA, like other trade deals are corporate welfare deasl. Why else would they be negotiated with the corporations while being kept secret from the public? Comment: Bob-thank you for the kind words.  Unfortunately, fund balances are not the result of intentionally collecting more taxes while knowing that expenses will be a lesser amount. Fund balances grow when warm winters resulting in less spent on snow removal and heating costs than budgeted, or because an entity experiences increased employee attrition.  Fund balances are not the result of simply asking for money than expected need.  Financial plans require expenditures to equal revenues, so in essence, a spending cap already exists with the current tax cap.

A new, unnecessary spending cap encourages short term waste of fund balances as government pumps up budgeted spending levels, using fund balances as a revenue source to enhance the level of future spending cap calculations.  I know that's not the intent, but that's what will happen.

Comment: "Invasion" isn't the right word for what's happened. For everything Ukraine was, no one was shooting at each other until the US decided they wanted a regime change. Ukraine is right up against the Russian border, and I can understand why the Russians aren't interested in a US puppet government in Ukraine. I'm sure the Russians are offering heavy support, but I've never seen evidence of a Russian invasion.

Crimea jumped ship. It's an ethnically Russian area, and has been part of Russia for longer than the US and Canada have been countries. It's also Russia's base for the Black Sea Fleet, a really important port. The Russians were never going to give that up. The other two provinces that ate fighting are also ethnically Russian, and were moved to Ukraine in a paperwork shuffle while the USSR was a thing.

NATO isn't even supposed to be in that area. Under the terms that NATO agreed to, they're not supposed to be in any former USSR states.

Comment: "Clearly you are not saying"
History, especially economic history, is anything but clear.
Yes, the "great communicator" said he was lowering taxes but actually raised them. In '82, there was the largest tax increase in history. He increased the size of government and therefor the GDP.
How was this miracle turn around from the inflationary Carter years?
First off, Volker raised interest rates, which was recessionary, but stopped the insidious inflation (caused by not paying for the Vietnam war with taxes). 
The biggest factor for this Reagan miracle of prosperity was DEBT.
The US government debt was $900 billion before he took office. In his 8 years he increased it to $2.7 trillion. It took 31 years to triple the debt and Reagan did it in 8.
Living large on debt has been the US business/lifestyle theme since then.
Great living on a trillion $s of debt a year, as long as you're the reserve currency. Debt doesn't matter, until the US is no longer the reserve currency. 
Viva la Dollar!

Comment: I am not avoiding the efficiency issue - I had stated that true equality could also be no religious holidays. Having only one group's holiday is the Orwellian principle of some people being more equal than others.

As for percentages, the percentage of Christians or Sikhs is 2 percent in India. Jains are less than 0.1 percent. At what stage does the minority religion become significant? 5 percent? 10 percent?

As for the public efficiency part, an economic fallout of Christmas is that all shops have to be closed (except pharmacies,maybe?). In India, when one religion is celebrating their festival, the stores and businesses of the other religion's traders and workers remain open. Why is the holiday enforced in such an anti-business way? After all, one should be free to decide whether to work that day or not. I believe that Boxing Day is also a required holiday for stores.

Finally, I have heard a lot of whining about not being able to say Merry Xmas. Say it, and wish others on their day

Comment: Somebody doesn’t understand basic math, basic physics.   

To be stable in flight a bullet spins like a football in a tight spiral.   This maintains velocity and accuracy over long distances.  In order to be less lethal many of the less than lethal rounds tumble the instant they leave the barrel.  They also have reduced powder loading.   This means the projectile leaves the barrel going slower, slows down faster upon exiting and hits across a larger area upon impact.   It also means the round is usable only in extremely short range situations with limited accuracy.   Such a round is entirely unsuited to accuracy beyond 50 feet at best.  As such it is worthless for plinking or target shooting or competition.   Any round that CAN stay accurate out to 200 yards will retain enough velocity/mass to cause lethal damage.

1. From where did you draw the statistic that "15+ million [sic] Canadians are addicted to booze"? That would be some 40% of the entire population.

Comment: Lessons from the PAST only go so far.  Canada no longer has the work gangs, assembly lines and office pools that employed so many 'til the mid 1970s.  By the 1990s, outsourcing of manufacturing began, then sped up to be joined by outsourcing of jobs.  Add new technologies intersecting with materials' science, and we don't have a substantial domestic workforce anymore. We have a 'just in time' or gig economy.

Canada has dished out approximately a million 10-year temporary resident visas EACH year since 2010 when the program began: 940,214 such visas in the first year -- but NO requirement to file income taxes as temp residents.. Add 300,000 new immigrants ... plus refugees. House prices UP, UP -- 

Canada must identify what it can do best instead of selling out to other nations. Too often, politicians tried to pick and subsidize economic 'winners'. Result: debts & deficits at all level. Technological change is SO rapid .. governments are slow and home to self-serving politicians.

Comment: What's "amiss" is the misunderstanding of the word "civil." I know what "uncivil" means to me: a comment that includes nasty gutter language, swearing, vehement, vicious comments against another person or his/her opinion.  To my mind: THAT defines "uncivil".  The other word NOT used that I believe means the same, is "Impolite."  Heaven forbid a Canadian should be "Impolite"!  Such an utterance puts our national cultural heritage in jeopardy! So we must pass a civility test.  Three times.

Which means a comment can be (1) ridiculous (2) incomprehensible (3) wrong-headed (4) slanderous (5) libellous (6) biased in the extreme but, if it is polite (read: civil) that's OK.

Meanwhile, somebody misunderstands the term and decides "uncivil" simply because they don't share the person's opinion.  Result: comment is gone.

Ironically, every day, you can read completely uncivil remarks because, well, people's line in the "civil" sand is drawn in a different place than yours or mine would be.

Comment: Makes sense for two reasons...
1. Amazon's brick-and-mortar bookstores are a joke... Their book selection is selected by algorithm based on online sales and ratings, so it's essentially what was popular 6 months ago. They have displays mimicking online recommendations (costumers who bought ... also bought ....) except Amazon's recommendations are notoriously bad online and not much better in-store. If Amazon is planning to expand into brick-and-mortar, they've realized they lack the experience to do it right.
2. Most retail growth is at the high end (e.g. Yorkdale mall) and low end (e.g. Dollarama), with middle-class retail (e.g. Sears) dying out. So if they are going to buy a grocery chain, it makes more sense to buy a brand (Whole Foods) over a middle-class brand.

Comment: To help you understand where I'm coming from , I've lived in Alaska nearly my whole life . Even though I grew up in Anchorage , I have many friends from all walks of life .That includes native friends. I'm a good listener and have learned a lot from so many. For example the myth that Alaskan natives only take what they need from nature and nothing more has proved wrong .In the past they took limited amounts of game because they didn't have the means to travel far or store food like they do today. When a native tells us on TV that they don't hunt the animals--the animals give themselves up to them--you know it's baloney  I KNOW that most commercial fishermen are from outside . My point was few die from primitive fishing . Look how a group of Bush fishermen refused to follow a river closure and only did so after their boats were taken. Look how native youth kill animals for kicks.  Many villages need to shut down and move to where they can survive . Their ancestors moved as needed .

Comment: We were happy to read your article and hope more folks take the plunge and try different ways to fix Ulu.
There are several videos on You Tube: John Cadman's and Sam Choy's are excellent, for both beginners and experienced cooks. Cleaning up kitchen utensils is easy using rags or paper towels and vegetable oil.
I personally have a pot and knives dedicated for Ulu when fixing several dishes. We have an Ulu orchard here in Kauai, growing the Ma'afala variety, and the trees are loaded this season. The short shelf life is a challenge. If you happen to visit, The Hanai Market in Kapaa carries ready-to-fry Ulu patties while Tom at Kilauea Bakery makes delicious bagels, bialys, and pies, and yes, Denby, we agree, why not Ulu pies for Thanksgiving?  We would love to see breadfruit offered in school cafeterias ourselves.
Thank you for the delightful way of bringing awareness to the amazing ULU.

Elli Ward

Comment: OK, let me clarify then. I did think Glenn's comment was offensive and inappropriate, and as I wrote, I flagged it as inappropriate (and did not feel it was worthwhile to repeat it). I do not agree, though, that the email prompt encourages a flip response; I really appreciate knowing when someone responds to something I wrote, so I can decide if I want to respond as well. I think the email alert encourages a complete discussion (rather than a fragment).

Comment: The resolution to automation is not to discourage it. It is going to happen regardless  what we do. If we ignore it our trading partners will eat our manufacturers' lunch.

One solution is to encourage a lot more small businesses serving local markets  However, this is old school and unlikely to put everyone who looses their job to automation back to work. Equally important is a change in attitude by ordinary people. 

Workers must adapt to the new jobs of the future rather than expect job to be tailored to their needs. Unfortunately the jobs of the future have not yet been created so workers cannot train for them until they arrive.

Our government should commit to more retraining programs as well as support to selective economic sectors that are showing success in this turbulent environment.

Comment: The "3% of services" figure is SO misleading as to be, in reality, false. PP arrives at that number by counting every little part of a service separately. Three months of birth control given at one time = 3 services. Two packs of condoms = 2 services. Come in for an abortion and they count at least 5 separate services (pregnancy test, ultrasound, use of facilities, post-procedure care, and the abortion itself - and any other things like STD testing, birth control, anesthesia, pain medication, prophylactic antibiotics - and that doesn't count all the services at the preparatory visit, so the actual abortion only counts as a small part of even the actual abortion visit.
A more accurate measure would be the fact that nearly half of PP's income is from abortions. In the last decade, the number of abortions they do has climbed, while the number of 'other services' has dropped dramatically. Every PP affiliate is required to perform abortions, and has a quota. Abortion is their main business.

Comment: Ben, 

If, as you note, the police aren't acting in response to criminal behavior occurring right in front of them, what -exactly- do you expect the property owner to do? If they are actually on the private property, as opposed to the sidewalk nearby, the owner's sole legal recourse is pretty much "call the police and have them trespassed." If the same ones return, call the police again and possibly have them arrested. Given reality, they are at worst going to be cited and kicked loose, as they'll claim indigence in the face of a fine and no one wants them cluttering up the jail.  

Yet how quickly would those same police, pushed by the bleeding hearts, ACLU, and our federal DOJ most likely, be to act to arrest, charge, and sue penniless a property owner who did anything more aggressive than the above?

So, again, on what rational or just basis could we hold dis-empowered property owners responsible for behavior they are not committing nor have any way to deter, prevent, nor control?

Comment: Your question is a good one and worthy of a response. As I see it, the teaching of Amoris Laetitia ch. 8 *qualifies* previous teaching that it is always mortally sinful to divorce, civilly remarry, and be sexually active in that new union. The qualification is that valid mitigating factors (a factor of our Catholic moral tradition) may prompt a person to follow this divorce-remarriage-sexual relationship path and that s/he may choose this path with an informed conscience (also a factor of our Catholic moral tradition) after having undergone the work of discernment of fault, goods, etc. in the internal forum. 

I accept that this is a negation of the universal statement that it is always mortally sinful to divorce, civilly remarry, and be sexually active in the new union. I believe rather that we should have all along been saying that it is *sometimes* mortally sinful to divorce, civilly remarry, and be sexually active in the new union. I do acknowledge that there is a difference here.

Comment: To be honest i don't know about the BBNC land issue, i do know that in order to file a claim on minerals it cannot be on private lands, under the law it only addresses claims on federal lands. the law is mainly covering the claim process, but there are more recent laws (Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 as an example) that have been enacted to fill the gaps, like the reclamation bonding for example under RCRA. On State lands it is a little different, usually a lease type situation. but, on private lands it's entirely different animal all together. 

leaching heavy metals? you know that these are naturally occurring right? the mining process just exposes more rock to the atmosphere which accelerates the oxidation rates of the minerals. being that this is a mass sulfide deposit, they will have sulfides which will make acid, granted no way around it. but, how they handle and deal with that is what is important and it can be dealt with and treated prior to release.

Comment: Let's assume, even at BLM'S count which is widely disputed, at best 75,000 wild horses left on the range, spread across 10 Western states. Fewer than 10 herds have over 1,000 animals. 1,500 is considered minimal for genetic viability. I haven't calculated it since last year, but there are around 5 - 8 million private cattle grazing on public lands. There are also millions of deer, elk antelope and other large grazing herbivores. You don't have to be a math wizard to see that wild horses make up less than 5% of all grazing animals.  Livestock outnumber wild horses on wild horse refuges by about 37 to 1. So let's please be serious about what's really decimating our rangeland resources.

Comment: "Reed lost faith in the Soviet Union."
John Reed, Oregonian from Portland,  radical,  writer, dreamer,  activist,  adventurer, Communist, only American buried in Moscow's Kremlin Wall.
But did he really  lose faith in the new Soviet Union before he died sudenly in 1920? .  That's been a subject of furious debate on the Left ever since.   Liberals tend to say he'd become  upset with the brutality and authoritarianism of the Bolsheviks, while radicals, and especially Communists, are likely to claim he still believed in his idealistic view of the Russian revolution as expressed in his classic "Ten Days That Shook the World."
While I've read most everything Reed wrote, and placed my hand on his niche in the Kremlin Wall, I  don't know.   I'd hope that had he not  suddenly died of typhus he would have been a moderating force on the developing Soviet state.
Fellow writer/activist  Louise Bryant, his wife who graduated from the UO, wrote of his terrible illness and Russia's reverence for him.

Comment: Mr Rae and others just adore referring to the 1985 Ontario election, but they are usually being more than a little disingenuous.

Certainly, after that election the Liberals formed a coalition with the NDP so that the Liberals could form the government.  However, the fact that Mr Rae and others rarely mention is the the Liberals had very nearly as many seats as the Tories and had a _larger_ share of the popular vote.

This event was not a case of two much smaller parties forming a coalition government - it was very much a case of the Liberals throwing the NDP a bone or two so that they would support a _Liberal_ government.  That Liberal government didn't need to build support for a coalition - they already had support from more voters than anyone else in the most recent election.

Comment: The mocking comments are beneath the dignity of G&M readers -- and they miss something important.

Yes, in episode 1 the French resemble 1950 movie villains and indigenous people have crude spears and rough camps. The vile British attacks on French settlements (civilians) goes unremarked, as does their motive of theft. Every story twist is made by the biggest & best. 

But the episode does give respect to Wendat economic reach and Haudenosaunee political and social sophistication. And as it reaches its climax, this is the pivot statement - "There was no way _not_ to have a Canada that was complicated by all of those relationships. It's just a question of how intelligently can we benefit from our mutual differences. And, eh, that is of course a challenge."

Despite limitations of the TV episode format, CBC conveyed a complex concept decisively. It is our creation story not a US clone, and a significant story to tell in this century. To get it, you have to not only look but _listen_.

Comment: I suppose the real question is, "Is discriminating against an Event the same as discriminating against a customer?"  This is what the Supreme Court will decide.  I understand both sides of the argument, but I still agree with the baker's right not to make a personalized cake (although my reasons are different than those the baker has stated).  I don't see this as discrimination but as an attempt at coercion to make the baker make a statement in violation of his personal beliefs.  If the baker doesn't want to personally support or endorse a certain type of event, that goes past what he is obligated to do as a business, in my opinion.  Some people might not have a problem making such statements, but he does, and I don't think being in business takes away his right not to make such statements.  In my opinion, designing a "plain" cake was the obvious solution, but I don't know if that solution was offered or not.

Comment: It's revealing to analyse this article's structure.

Paragraphs 1-6 are about Britain (which has educationally "stumbled") needing the teaching help of China (which is advancing towards "soft superpower").
Paragraphs 7-26 are about China investing in education (partly in response to shortcomings, and partly to develop international academic exchange) whilst seeking an intellectual environment to retain its high achievers.
Then paragraphs 27-39 go back to how Britain would benefit from educationally following China (which would lead to UK children "outperforming the UK curriculum").
And the heading indicates that all this about "export opportunity".

It's as if the article were written with two purposes: to report developments in Chinese education; and to show that Britain isn't as good as China (which would marginalize British comment), against a background of trade (which is currently a Chinese success and a British concern).

(Continued in a second part.)

Comment: Groupon!!  Best headline of the day:

Cost to see VP Mike Pence in Denver plummets after tickets struggle to sell
The original minimum ticket for the Mike Pence event was $275. Now it’s $150.
Because of a lack of demand, the Colorado Republican Party is offering a Groupon-like deal to see Vice President Mike Pence.

Pence is the headliner for a party fundraiser Oct. 26 at the Denver Marriott Tech Center, where the minimum-priced tickets originally cost $275.

The party announced the event weeks earlier but struggled to sell the 800 tickets available. So now it’s lowering the lowest-price ticket to $150, a 45 percent discount. A couple can attend with a two-for-one deal at the original $275 price.

Denver Post

Comment: I happen to know a lot about speculation, trading, and price trends. The premise of this article is wrong. Speculators may be adding to market demand in the short term, but they did not create the upward price trend. They are latching on to an existing trend, not causing it. If prices were flat, they would not speculate. If prices were declining, they would be selling, not buying.

Speculators actually perform a legitimate function. They provide liquidity in the market, and help prices move to their natural level, which they clearly have not done in Toronto yet. They are also taking a big risk for their efforts, which most people don't realize. Things can decline at any time. When that happens, they could end up taking huge losses. That's happened before, and it will happen again.

Sousa was asking Morneau to introduce a tax on home speculation, which I'm glad he didn't do. It is ridiculous to want to change the tax system for one price trend in one market.

Comment: That's interesting.  What accounts for all the ice ages, mini and grand, and all the climate changes before the industrial revolution.  The earth is billions of years old and yet in the the last 150 years humans are the main cause of these changes?  Maybe, but is it also possible that scientific opinion itself has been politicized in our acrid social climate?  Perhaps there is too much money at stake for scientists to disagree with any pre-established political agendas.  Yes, we should do all we can to be good stewards of nature, but I would not put all my eggs in the basket of  "man made" climate change.  I think there is enough evidence on both sides to keep the dialogue open, rather than castigate those who disagree with either point of view.  Open mindedness to all points of view best serves the scientific method of inquiry until an hypothesis is tested proven and repeatable under stringent conditions.  I don't think we are there yet and if we close our minds we will never arrive.

Comment: As a veteran with more than thirty-five years of active duty, I fail to see how the Trump administration’s review of national monuments is an affront to military service.   What the Trump administration is doing is reviewing the massive and unprecedented Federal land grab under the Obama administration, much of it just a week before he left office.  Captain Perez is correct about many national monuments being treasures that tell the story of our military.  I would be offended and outraged it the Trump administration was to rescind or reduce any in size, but I seriously doubt such will happen.  I believe the review is focusing primarily on the hundreds of thousand acres of wide open spaces ranchers once used to graze cattle but were forced out by Obama’s unprecedented expansion and creation of new national monuments, perhaps to protect a few wild animals and to keep environmentalists happy.  I will reserve judgement until I see the results of the Trump review.

Comment: In one of the stories that inspired this column (The Star), a prof. Of psychiatry (U of Calgary) made the bold pronouncement that students have never before faced the level of stress that they face today.

First: how would the prof know? She is less than 50 years old, so let's discount personal experience.
Second: no studies on levels of student stress were likely undertaken at ANY time in the 20th century...

That would include the stress levels of kids who managed to go to university during the dirty 30s' Great Depression (before student loans, except what uncles and grandparents provided). That would include returning WW II vets, some suffering from what we now call PTSD, fast-tracked through programs in double-quick time, so they could get jobs to support new wives they barely knew any longer and children born during their time away. 

Student stress ain't new. My father certainly felt it. And survived it. Was it more that today's stress? Don't know. Neither does the professor.

Comment: This is indeed a chiropractic ad, and it's outrageous that the Globe should print it at a time when Ottawa has made a political football of the 20% or more of adult Canadians who suffer with severe chronic pain by depriving them of the opioids they need to have any kind of life, and which has been legally and expertly prescribed for them. What's Ottawa getting for its attack on the sick and the vulnerable? In the US, the anti-opioid war was started by insurance companies and rehab centers and Ottawa is blindly following without any regard to the elephant in the room - the street addicts who make up more than 99% of opioid overdose deaths. Chronic pain patients are not contributing to this problem and there is no evidence to suggest otherwise. When called out on this, we hear of "emerging evidence", aka non-existent.
Opioids are the gold standard for treating bad pain. Chiropractors have a tenuous grip on public confidence, and, given a choice I'd be more inclined to sacrifice a goat.

Comment: Something to ponder.  In March 2016, Japan Rail Corporation opened its Shinkansen (bullet train) line linking the islands of Honshu and Hokkaido.  The dual track line is 149 kilometers long (92.5 miles) and runs 23% on viaducts (21.2 miles), 4% on bridges (3.7 miles), and 65% in tunnels (62 miles) and it cost was 550.8 billion yen ($4.67 billion).  That is about $50.4 million per mile.  HART, if it ever gets finished, will be 20 miles long and at current estimates will cost $500 million per mile, or ten times more per mile than it cost the Japanese to build its new Hokkaido line.  New York’s East Side Access is 6 miles in a tunnel.   Current cost estimate is $10.2 billion or $1.7 billion per mile, or 34 times more than the Japanese rail project.  Yes, there are differences in labor and materials cost between the three locations, but 10 and 34 times more?  I do think so.  It seems to me HART and NYC hired the wrong people for their rail projects.

Comment: Every case is different, there is simply no formula that fits all. My husband deferred his CPP until age 70, and died at age 73. Since he was getting maximum benefits, I got maximum survivor's benefits. A year after my husband died, I turned 60, and although I personally am not entitled to maximum benefits, it simply made sense to start cashing in my CPP right at age 60, since combining my benefits with the survivor's benefits brings me very close to maximum benefits allowable at age 65. In dollar amount, that's just over $112,000 until I reach age 70. I would have been a complete fool to defer.

Comment: Hikers at least have opportunity to use good judgment: "Hmm...this area is completely encircled by head-high brush.  I can't see far in any direction.  I'd better not go in there."

Runners have less time/opportunity to do so by virtue of the rate at which they're moving, but can still sometimes change course to avoid danger.  Mountain-yuppies hurtling at speed down low-visibility trails have still less opportunity, again simply by virtue of rate-of-travel.

Which as been the point all along--moving rapidly through low-visibility terrain in bear country is dangerous--doesn't matter whether you're running, biking or sliding down on a piece of cardboard.  Moreover, the danger isn't only for you, but for others on the trail endangered by your irresponsible behavior, and of course the bears themselves.

I oppose bear-baiting.  Even by reckless morons who volunteer to be the bait--because, AGAIN, they risk others' lives besides their own.

Comment: Alberta almost froze solid - but thanks to coal we didn't.
Here in Alberta, we had steady - 30 lows to -20 C highs over a 3 week period. We set power consumption records on a daily basis. Almost all of this electricity was provided by natural gas and coal because - it was a cold air mass that had very little air movement.  Therefore the installed wind power contributed little electricty. If just our coal power had not been available, and we had trusted renewables to carry this load, our economy and culture would have shut down under emergency power rationing. If our cars were also electric, it would have taken the crisis to another extreme as we could not have recharged them - we would have been house bound - not for hours but for 3 weeks. Recklessly pushing renewables without considering reliability of supply is irresponsible and weakens the arguments made for green.

Comment: Overall, this was a good article, but I have to disagree with the author that income sprinkling is somehow justified.  It is not, simple as that.  Employees do not have the ability to sprinkle income to other family members, so why should a business owner? Full disclosure, I own two businesses and yes, I do what is legal under the current tax rules.  I also get business risk, believe me, but they are two totally unrelated issues.  You should own and run a business because the risk/return relationship is favourable.  You don't own a business with the expectation of the govt supporting your feasibility by allowing the owner to sprinkle income to kids.  It's not just doctors, it is also lawyers, accountants, business owners of private companies, etc..  The govt doesn't owe you a special tax break that others don't get (deferred income).  The govt shouldn't allow you expense deductions that others don't get (i.e. write off phone bills, home office, car usage, meals, computers, etc..).

Comment: I actually think both Bush and maybe Clinton were looking at something like 5% of total funding being invested in the stock market.   That would be huge windfall for stockholders in the first year as it would create buying pressure, but after that, I don't see it as such a big deal.

I think 5% of social security being in the stock market would be fine.  It would force some money into long term holding, not sure that fits the pay as you go structure of today.

Comment: Yes, I remember paying the state income tax.  I also remember the original arguments that a Permanent Fund would generate funds to allow removal of the state income tax.  Once we walked away from the Cremo concept (spending only what we earned from the Permanent Fund  the year before) we trapped ourselves into an unhealthy dependence on short term oil revenue.  We also allowed large portions of this state to remain dependent on the state for government services.  Generations of legislators denied that oil is a ultimately non-renewable resource and no amount of promises or inducements to find more can overcome that fact.   
   A population our size cannot generate the necessary tax revenues that don't risk creating more problems.   "Modest" is a very subjective term.  For instance 50% of property taxes in Anchorage currently pay for  schools.  Is that "modest"?  
  I am not anti-tax; however, I will balk at the idea of paying income tax to pay myself a Permanent Fund Dividend.

Comment: There are already dozens of cheap generics that are either completely unavailable or on back order at every pharmacy. If a physician prescribes Penicillin for strep, which is always sensitive to penicillin, he/she will get an immediate call from the pharmacy stating that it is not available but another (more expensive) product is. Eventually, when this happens often enough - and it does - the physician takes the path of least resistance and starts prescribing the expensive alternative instead of the cheap one. 
The government needs to set up a non-profit crown corporation to manufacture these cheap, generic medications in quantity. It would provide jobs. A non-profit organisation could make them cheaper. It would be perfectly legal since the patent protection ran out long ago.  It could be a source of needed drugs for undeveloped countries.  And it would provide the common drugs that big pharma have shown they are not interested in producing.

Comment: The topic of marijuana and driving is complex.   

Data out of the state of Washington is compelling.  The data taken before, during and after adult use of recreational marijuana became legal is clearly indicating significant harm to others when a driver uses marijuana. 

Drivers testing positive for active marijuana (indicating use within hours), no other drugs or alcohol, in a fatal crash were FIVE TIMES more likely to have KILLED someone other than themselves compared to a driver testing positive for alcohol alone. 

During the test period of about five years, drivers testing positive for active marijuana KILLED more bicyclists, pedestrians, passengers and other drivers than drivers using alcohol even though there were significantly fewer marijuana drivers. 

We hypothesize that these drivers have impaired visual functions and do not actually see the person or other vehicle.  Or see them inaccurately.

Our functional test IMMAD, in an app for law enforcement, tests this.

Comment: "The reason is something called “global adjustments” – a fee to cover the cost of green energy and conservation programs that is unrelated to the actual cost of electricity itself."

And Wente starts off the New Year with an old lie... or else more lazy misinformation, her stock in trade.

The Global Adjustment covers the difference between hourly market rates and long-term contractual power rates. Most goes to nuclear plant operators, and less than 20% to wind and solar power providers. The rationale for the GA goes back to the breakup of Ontario Hydro under the Harris PCs, along with the long-standing artificially-low subsidized power rates in the province that did not cover the cost of maintenance and replacement of infrastructure, particularly aging nuclear plants.

https://onlineacademiccommunity.uvic.ca/2060project/2016/01/13/understanding-ontarios-global-adjustment/
http://www.ieso.ca/Documents/Understanding_GA_Jan_2016.pdf

Comment: I don't follow your reasoning. 

If there was no implied contract between the cabbie and the complainant, then he owed her no duty of care as a passenger.

Your second assertion makes no sense that I can see.

This ruling creates no such legal precedent. As far as I know, the rules around consent and sexual assault were written by the Supreme Court of Canada. It doesn't get any more precedential than that.

No person, highly intoxicated or not, may be sexually assaulted. And whether or not you're highly intoxicated, saying "No" means exactly that. A physical attempt to engage in sex after that refusal is an assault. But looking at it after the fact, if the complainant says he can't remember whether he gave consent or not, it will be very difficult to prove that a crime was committed.

There is a simple remedy. Unless you're in a very safe place, don't drink to the point where you can't remember what you did or said.

Comment: I wonder how much attention planners have paid to the fate of bays and harbors in the Indian Ocean tsunami of 2004.  

I had previously wondered how directional a major tsunami moving parallel to a coastline would be  --  would it rush past a harbor like PA's or would it expand into everything it passed?  So I paid close attention to the effects of that catastrophic and widespread tsunami.  From everything I could see, a tsunami going past a bay  --  as opposed to slapping perpendicularly into one  --  causes a narrow cone of damage on the far entrance to the bay.  

It seems likely that soil liquefaction will be a far greater hazard in the PA harbor area than tsunami.

Very clearly, the system is abused to remove comments merely because people don't agree with the opinion expressed.  I have also had the system inform me that I was "biased" in my reviewing of other comments.  When I'm required to review others' comments in order to post my own,  I only flag a comment as not civil, if it isn't civil, ie: contains personal insults, name calling or other extraneous antagonism. Comment: Keonimay, The Coast Guard, like the Navy, is a military service, but its mission is significantly different than the Navy’s.  The CG’s mission is to protect the public, the environment and U.S. economic interest.  The Navy’s mission is to maintain, train and equip combat-ready Naval forces capable of winning wars, deterring aggression and maintaining freedom of the seas.  Each service requires equipment tailored to its mission.  Ships used by the Navy are primarily deep water vessels equipped with weapons designed for warfare.  Most CG ships are designed to operate in shallow coastal waters, are smaller, faster and more maneuverable than Navy ships and have much lighter weaponry than Navy ships.  Although the CG has sometimes used U.S. Navy ships, most of them do not meet CG needs.

Comment: Just because natural variation in the amount of energy we get from the sun (called 'insolation') has driven climate change in the past, doesn't mean that's what's going on today.
.
Right now insolation is going *down*, and the planet *should* be cooling, but it's not. It's not, because heating from CO2 is overwhelming the cooling from decreased insolation.
.
Here’s a simple proof of global warming that doesn't depend on any assumptions or predictions:
.
1st. CO2 levels have been rising sharply ever since the industrial revolution, when we started releasing massive amounts of stored carbon. This graph shows what that looks like. Note the sharp spike on the right hand side:
https://scripps.ucsd.edu/programs/keelingcurve/wp-content/plugins/sio-bluemoon/graphs/co2_10k.png
.
2nd. CO2 traps heat. The more CO2, the more heat.
.
You can't fight physics, if we're trapping more heat, then the planet is heating up.

Comment: As I recall from twenty or so years ago, well managed investment accounts were returning close to 10% on notes issued by FNMA and GNMA, on municipal bonds, and on other instruments.  I don't recall that anyone was credibly predicting an end to the long economic expansion after WW II, and a guaranteed 7.5% return seemed like a safe bet.  But GDP growth has slowed to a snail's pace over the last decade for a variety or reasons that economists and everyone else are arguing over.  How quickly we forget the past, so that now 1% GDP and near 0% return on investment ( and even negative returns on bonds! ) seem to be accepted as the new normal.  Perhaps in twenty years returns will again be generous, and those retirees stuck with accounts returning 2% will be screaming?  Who knows?

My point is that it's easy in hindsight to blame others for their lack of foresight, which would have required a working crystal ball.  But future contracts should promise only what the markets return.

Comment: I've read these renewable jobs claims in the past and would like to see a more detailed analysis of what constitutes a renewable job vs a fossil fuel job. I'm quite sure installing solar panels on a roof would be a renewable job, so does installing asphalt shingles count as fossil fuel job?

I recently read an article that claimed that total renewable energy jobs outnumbered fossil fuel jobs. The latest electrical generation figures from the EIA from 2015 break down the US 4 trillion kilowatts market like this, coal 33%, natural gas 33%, nuclear 20%, hydro 6%, petroleum 1%, renewables other than hydro 7% (wind 4.7%, biomass 1.6%, solar .6%, geothermal .4%). These figures do not even take into consideration the energy used by the transportation industry which almost exclusively relies on fossil fuels.

So based on the statistical analysis of the watts, btu or joules of energy per job, fossil fuels, if they truly are fewer in number, deliver a vastly superior return to the consumer.

Comment: I'm not sure of the amount, but initially 100% of the mining royalties went to the general fund. They never imagined it would create such an excess, they had only hoped it would reduce the state income tax. 2 or 3 years they eliminated the income tax, created the pf were 50% of resource royalties went into gf the rest into the pf where the pfd would be paid off the interest to the people, as the minerals are by law the people's. About 8 years ago the pfd was recalculated to be a 5 yr average payout. During the palin administration, she distributed an additional 2k out of the general fund(the reserve), because the economy was stagnant and the state was setting on about 50 billion dollars in the reserve with 100+ $ a barrel oil coming in. Btw last calculation I heard on the reserve, it was over 12 billion or 3 to 4 year reserve with zero income. Most states reserves are 10 to 15 day reserve, we have the highest reserve in the US by years.

Comment: Informing clients is fine, but what happens after may not be.  For instance, I, too, received a recommendation from a teller to see a financial planner.  Fine.  However, it turned out that the planner put me in high-fee mutual funds (while I was only using the e-series low-fee funds) - and only he could make transactions! - and even sent me to a self-directed RRSP (again, only he could make transactions in it), with a $50 fee plus HST, while I only had $17,000 in my RRSP, in the form of  only 4 GICs three years away from maturing - clearly, this was non-sense intended to collect fees.   He may have disclosed this RRSP charge, but I missed it.  When I discovered that a year later, I basically "fired" that financial planner and went to self-investing instead - and unwound the self-directed RRSP.  So it back-fired, as he no longer collects his fees.  Anyway, be careful when you meet that so-called planner: that person is quite likely to push products that may not be suitable for you.

Comment: Yeah great! Let's continue, for political reasons, to support the market-driven death of coal. This is not winning. Comment: The "blind bidding" is a feature of the market here that is as bad as "gazumping" is in the UK property market.    Gazumping is so bad that it actually is a word that means "to swindle". 

The practice of massively overshooting the list price on the first bid (by 20% or more) happens so much at the moment it's suspicious.   For example, does that so-so semi down the street in a catchment with so-so schools really warrant $220k over the asking price of $799k?

I also have been hearing of stampedes of people attending open houses and have to wonder if all are really interested in the housing market, or are there some people being paid (or otherwise incented) to create "traffic" and make people increase the amount they bid.   Some of the open house attendance numbers I've heard are so high they are ridiculous.   They aren't credible given how often there are on-line viewing options now.

Comment: Now that we have turned the corner and  light is returning, it is time to really ask what our particular area can do to generate jobs. In southeast, there are lots of resources and limited access to them, such that an area which used to have a healthy, non-government economy is at great risk.  Solutions?

I"m thinking that a place like southern southeast (Prince of Wales Island) could market health by doing things like constructing a soft track for runners, and marketing that in areas that are too hot to live in half the year. This could lengthen the relatively short summer season to 6 months, bringing much needed cash to the area. Not only would personal income increase, but tax revenue would go up as well. That is just an example of an idea for my area; each area of the state has its own particular assets. We need to learn to more efficiently use what we do have.

My heart goes out to the families affected by this downturn: best luck!

Comment: [cont'd]

Math is a language. It's a language that is full of precise terminology. The terminology can sometimes get in the way of a child's desire to learn a new skill and to understand when & why & how to apply it. My own approach was to 'keep it simple' at first, let the kids gain confidence and introduce the finer points & terminology later on. Most people don't need to know that the answer to a division problem is called the quotient. But it's certainly important for us to know when to use the 'operation' and how to obtain the correct answer.

One last point: a teacher who is side-stepping certain curriculum expectations or the strong recommendation of a principal/director may be reluctant to share that with parents. Teachers know that for many kids (the unmotivated, confused, distressed, distracted, etc) hammering away at the prescribed curriculum will do more harm than good. 

Nothing succeeds like success. The challenge is, how best to bring it about for each student.

Comment: I assume $5 billion would be conventional diesel commuter rail with a max speed of 79 mph. And the $15 billion estimate would be for high speed electric commuter rail simular to Amtraks northeast corridors Accela trains which have a max speed of 150 mph.

Here's the thing, spend less and it will be a waste. 79 mph diesel trains running 2-4 times a day won't be popular. Even though it only costs $5 billion from Pueblo to Fort Collins which isn't bad on a cost per mile basis, it 2ill be too slow and not frequent enough to attract riders; making it a waste.

Of you spend $15 billion and get 150 mph train a that run 12 times a day, then you have something faster than driving and frequent enough you can easily integrate it into your schedule. The ridership would be much higher; thus making it more viable and worth the investment.

So I must warn either do high speed rail, or don't do it at all. Anything less than high speed rail will be a waste of money.

Comment: Good point.

One thing that appears to have been missed here is that this form of consolidation tends increase - not decrease - administration & expenses.

UAA serves far more education students than UAF.

For this arrangement to work effectively:

* UAA, UAF and UAS will need local Dean-equivalents. The title may change but the job will be the same.

* UAF will need to hire an additional super-Dean (with support staff) or will need to provide additional staff and support to the existing UAF Dean to cover the additional responsibilities.

*  Senior Faculty on all three campuses will need to reallocate their time (especially in the first year) to ensure effective coordination.  If this reallocation reduces research - UA will lose research funding (which includes indirect funding to cover overhead costs).  If this reduces teaching - faculty will need to be hired, or class sizes will increase, or class offerings will be reduced.  if this reduces enrollment, tuition revenue will fall.

Comment: The flu vaccine is a huge scam.  There is no evidence that it is effective. To date there is only one gold standard clinical trial with the flu vaccine that compares vaccinated vs. unvaccinated. This double-blind placebo controlled study following the health conditions of vaccinated and unvaccinated children between the ages of 6-15 years for 272 days. The trial concluded the flu vaccine holds no health benefits. 

The Department of Justice regularly releases a report on settlements made for vaccine injuries and deaths. The most recent report was issued on December 2, 2016, identified the flu vaccine as the most dangerous vaccine in the U.S., harming more people than all the other vaccines combined. The flu shot’s vaccine court settlement payments increased from $4.9 million in 2014 to $61 million in 2015, an increase of more than 1000%. 

But the science and the facts won't convince those who belong to the vaccine religion.

Comment: "It’s a power-grab by the Liberals, plain and simple,” Mr. Rankin said. “The Parliament is for the people of Canada. It’s not to make the government’s work more efficient. It’s to hold the government to account.”
No no no, Mr. Rankin.  It may be the role of opposition parties to hold the government to account, but it is not the role of Parliament to do that.  Opposition parties certainly need a minimum time to hold the government to account, but this does not imply that they should be allowed to do this beyond that minimum necessary time.
The role of Parliament is to pass legislation, with the consent of the governed as expressed by their representatives.  If a majority of representatives favours new legislation, that legislation should be passed.  
It is not an expression of democracy when a minority of representatives holds up legislation that is favoured by the majority. 
It is troubling that Conservative and NDP members do not understand this.

Comment: It's clear that we need this expanded housing, so it feels natural just to read this and think, "Good."

But I can't forget that this whole huge project wasn't even in the City's plans when it came up for the Opportunity Fund grant this year.  That's especially striking when the Housing Authority's director says the project is "long overdue" and "the largest development in years."  --  it does seem like the sort of undertaking that would need good, solid advance planning.

There are other worrisome things about this report  --  e.g., shouldn't the reengineering of part of the city's street grid be based on more than "They said high school kids fly down Park [Avenue]"?   You know, something old-fashioned like data?

I certainly wish this project well  --  and have the uneasy feeling that it may need luck to replace the solid analysis and planning that seems not to have been done.

Comment: The Liberals initially thought the NDP could be forced to fight a losing 2 front campaign against:

1. the Greens for middle-class voters who focus on environmental issues, and 

2. the Liberals for blue collar voters who put jobs over environmental concerns  

and therefore opened by stressing their commitment to economic expansion and downplayed the environment.

However, during the campaign, the Liberals found many GVRD and Island supporters gravitating to the Greens out of (a) environmental concerns, (b) disenchantment with the Liberals and (c) a conclusion the Greens were a safe non-NDP option.

In the campaign’s closing days, by targeting thermal coal the Liberals are playing the nationalist and environmental cards to draw back traditional support in a way that they think will not turn off the Interior’s blue collar voters.

The Liberals thereby risk confirming by this shifting about the public perception that they are a shifty lot, not to be trusted

Comment: Recent essays on "Abba" suggest that it was indeed a common term for father, or more accurately "my father", to distinguish from formal terminology used at the time. In the middle east (and among people of middle eastern ancestry in the US), the father holds ultimate power over all family decisions, even those of adult children, no matter how impassioned the arguments. Shaming the father by bad behavior by children severed the relationship. Hence the shock of the message of the story of the prodigal son. 

Interpreting Abba as "Daddy" diminishes the obligation of respect and obedience as well as decision-making authority that children of all ages were expected to hold toward their father. (Gaza Vermes  (1983), in Jesus and the World of Judaism, gives a linguistic explanation.)  

By using Abba, Jesus made the point that God was deeply personal and merciful, and as involved as any earthly father, and conveyed his position as an obedient son of the Father, not a rebel or heretic.

Comment: Reread the column; did not – and have never – supported censorship ... Comment: Keaaloha alludes to Nash Equilibrium in referring to "zero sum". Outside of the land issue, this is a reason why economic Game Theory is off kilter. Hawaii as a state is unique when it comes to federal law and all the lands and waters of the Hawaiian Islands. Its the only state where federal Indian policy is recognized by Congress as where all the land (and water) is considered having Indian title. In all other states, only some lands are trust lands. The closet parallel is the Navajo lands. So it probably is the reality that even if not reserved per se, the Mauna lands are also trust lands of the Hawaiian Community, which incorporates the native Hawaiians for whom reserved lands were set aside as protected by direct federal jurisdiction from taking by none other than the federal government. The state administers this trust but is biased against both federal policy and the Hawaiian community. There cannot be a fair trial and thus due process where the process is biased fundamentally.

Comment: I find this new movement of trying to label oneself very interesting. When I was young, I looked almost exactly the same as Nicholas, very androgynous, but I was female.  I was so upset when anyone tried to label me (calling me a dyke, fag, queer, tom-boy, etc.). I wanted to avoid labels; I was a woman, and being a woman can mean a lot of different things. Now everyone is straining to come up with as many new labels as there are people. It's kind of sad, really, because I feel like it is trying to separate us rather than unite us. We are all human, we are all born on a continuum of male/female; your clothes, hair, makeup, mannerisms, etc. do not make you male or female. Your DNA, hormones, gene expression, is unique for each person, but it doesn't make each person a new species. A man with long hair and makeup is not a woman, a woman with short hair and jeans is not a man. They are what they are, and that should be OK. It should be enough. I would prefer just one label, "human."

We've focused our resources at the far end of the continuum of services.....locked-ward incarceration and, by doing so, have insured that those other programs will be underfunded (or unfunded) and those individuals in need will not be helped.  

The JC facility needs to be closed.  Those patients needing "locked-ward" placement need to be housed in Salem and those patients in the hospital system (JC and Salem) who can be better and for cost-effectively service in small community-based facilities need to go there.  This could release millions to be dedicated to those sorely needed community-based programs.  

regards, Gary

Comment: Geeez . . . if logging profit is the only thing that saves our forestlands from burning, how did they ever survive before intensive logging began 100+ years ago? Did the First Nations engage in clearcutting and industrial milling? 

In reality, it was intensive logging that created a possibility of catastrophic fires that didn't exist before. A healthy, biodiverse, mature forest is fire resistant, even needs fire to clear out brush and create spacing between mature trees.

Cutting and replanting puts us in a vicious cycle where only more logging and replanting protects the replanted forests--usually crowded, single species plantations of young trees--from going up in flames or succumbing to pests or both.

Comment: When the eye came over land in the Naples area about 120 miles south of Tampa Irma started to fall apart. This is critical for any storm. They can't regenerate like they can over water and the frictional force disrupt circulation. Also as flat as Florida is just east of the Naples area is one of the highest parts of the state with rolling hills which break storms up.

I didn't ride it out - I stayed with a friend close by who was better protected by surrounding trees and buildings and 35 feet above sea level. If you are within a mile of water and less than 10 feet above sea level you are crazy to not leave. Its not cool or macho or whatever. Its a giant pain to be sitting in the dark hot, sweaty, no TV, etc. Its like how people have been swept away in the streams there in thigh deep water. You might make it wading across but its a certainty that if you don't try you won't die. For noobies to Florida every storm is a learning experience. We need to send them the right message.

Comment: Thanks for that detailed explanation (which I wasn't aware of) but I was referring to a defence lawyer trying to claim that an accused robber had consent to take someone's money or property. A defence lawyer isn't going to do his client any good by arguing that he had consent while holding a gun in someone's face.

But let's take the analogy closer to the case here. Say the robber knocks the lady down while snatching her purse, rendering her unconscious. When she comes to she's unable to recall anything about the incident. Does the robber get off by claiming he had consent to take her purse, a claim that she can't refute? Barring a case with no witnesses, no evidence of an assault and a victim with a history of losing consciousness, I would say not. Unfortunately, that's the situation in this case. There's no witnesses, no evidence of an assault, and the purported victim can't remember a thing.

Comment: As the mom of the child allergic to wheat, dairy, eggs, peanuts, tree nuts and shellfish, I would like to respond to your comments. (a) While it poses challenges, I would not call it "awful" but thank you for your compassion. Stress results from the implication that he should manage this by himself.  He is a child who needs support & guidance from the adults around him, especially at school where he spends most of his day. (b) all of his allergens are not restricted in his school.  Together with the school staff, we have applied strategies that reduce his risk of exposure to allergens. Each child's needs are different & 1-size-fits-all approach is not the way. Factors such as age, maturity, where kids eat (cafeteria vs classroom) should be considered. Steps to limit risk of exposure & education are not mutually exclusive; to be effective they need to go hand in hand. The issue is the lack of guidance to Boards and schools about practical and realistic steps needed to keep kids safe.

Comment: When I moved to Lorane 30 year ago this past August My first job was as a carpenter building, along with others, the wood forms for the house and tying the reinforcing steel, and then assisting with the pumped concrete for the shell. I remember that the form for the bathroom was a horse trailer. I also did some of the interior wet plastering of the walls.

Coincidentally, I also rented the log cabin on two O&C homesteads belonging to Lorane pioneers Harry and Helen Jahnke, a beautiful and wild property on Fawn Creek, a tributary of Siuslaw River, which had a small waterfall with leaping coho salmon in the early winter. This property was recently logged by the McDougal brothers and sold to its present owner, Nolan Scheid, who is a very nice man.

Structurally, the shell of this home probably is sound, but there may be significant water damage. I have heard that it has always leaked.

Property prices in Lane County are outrageous. Put the reconstruction cost on top of that.

Comment: I am disappointed at Ms. Wente's lack of research, and disappointed that the Globe and Mail editors chose to run this article as written. "Who knew that Law students were suffering so much?" That is a phenomenon that is well documented in scientific and legal journals, is known by law societies and law schools, and has been highlighted in various media articles over the past several years. The evidence is clear that within two months of law school, many students begin a decline in mental health that continues into their professional life and culminates in serious illnesses such as depression, anxiety, OCD and alcoholism. Law students and lawyers are particularly affected by these illnesses, which affect a shockingly high percentage of them. It is a problem that has been exacerbated by the attitude that Ms. Wente displays, and it feeds into self-stigma and reluctance of law students and lawyers to seek help for even serious mental distress and illnesses.

Comment: Sigh, my parents just sold the family cottage on the weekend.  It will be sad to see it go in a few weeks, but the reality is that it costs a lot to keep it going & my parents should now look to using the money for their retirement as their health declines.  When I was a kid we drove up when school ended and came back to the city just in time to go back to school.  In the summer we worked at local parks and restaurants and made lifelong friends.  However as my siblings and I have married and had families of our own, things have changed.  None of us can afford to keep it going ourselves; when both parents work, there isn't the stretch of time in the summer to spend there; and weekend traffic doesn't always make it a worthwhile trip.  Finally, I have always said I would rather lose the cottage than fight over property with my siblings (and I guarantee there would be disagreements).  We will sadly say goodbye and focus on making different, but still special, memories for our kids.

Comment: Yes, and 100 employees is probably a low estimate of what it would take to run the Alaska State IRS:

If you look at the Federal IRS, they have about 80,000 employees. They handle tax returns for a population of 321,000,000. That's a ratio of 1:4013 (population to IRS employees). If we use that ratio to extract what Alaska might require with its population of 738,000, you would need 184 employees to manage, audit, and enforce tax collection.

And using the IRS ratio is probably low -- the IRS complains all the time that they can't do the job properly with their resources, resulting in low audit rates. And the IRS has a long history and some economy of scale. So an Alaska IRS would probably struggle with a 184-employee workforce.

I believe I saw $35 million as a State estimate for the annual costs of income tax collection from a previous article. Given these estimates for State agencies usually end up exceeding estimates, I believe your $50 million is correct and probably conservative.

Comment: Good grief, yourself.  Yes, CO2 is a greenhouse gas, but  a relatively incidental one.  The primary greenhouse gas is water vapor, but even that isn't the primary cause of climate change.  The sun is.  Our orbit is constantly changing in shape, and our distance from the sun constantly changes; the sunspot activity varies and constantly changes the amount of solar radiation we receive; and the tilt of the earth's axis constantly changes, and even "flips" the positive and negative poles over time.  When we're closer to the sun, it warms, and when we're further away, we have ice ages.  And there's nothing we can do about it but adapt to the changes as they happen.

Comment: A couple of differences:   
- The greatest difference is capacity, LRT can move far more people than buses.   LRT' accelerate quicker so there can be shorter lead time between vehicles.  They have greater seating capacity than buses.  

- As electric vehicles they are much quieter than buses and will not pollute the surrounding area.  This makes them perfect for intensely urban areas like King Street.    

- Electric LRT are less costly to maintain than gas powered vehicles.   

- More people per LRT vehicle means fewer drivers and a lower operating cost.  

- LRT operate in tracks which means stations can be wheel chair accessible.

Comment: "But when we first read The Communist Manifesto or Capital, Marxism seemed like a great idea, too. In reality, of course, communism turned out to be a nightmare, providing neither equality nor freedom to its people."

MSW, this is a rather facile statement:  rhetorically it makes your point, but only because it appeals to the canard that Marxism=Soviet Communism.  As most scholars of the field (and not just leftist scholars) will tell you, you have to draw an clear distinction between the ideas of Marx himself and their later development:  one of which was Soviet style communism, but there are other schools of non-authoritarian Marxist thought.  When discussing Marx himself (e.g., the Manifesto or Capital) it is customary to refer to Marxian ideas--most of which were a critique of capitalism and almost none of which were about "communism", however defined.

Comment: The 2.2% of minimum wage worker who are single parents are entitled to the federal Working Income Tax Benefit.  

To someone working 1,500 hours per year, it's worth about an extra $1.15 per hour.  To someone working 2,000 hours per year, the WITB drops to about $866, or $.43 per hour, but at that level of employment, the minimum wage employee will face paying $168 for the regressive and arbitrary Ontario Health Levy.

If Kathleen Wynne was interested in anything other than votes and spending, she'd put an end to the Ontario Health Levy for low income workers.  

Instead, she's squeezing small businesses that will be forced to eliminate jobs and, for those employees lucky enough to maintain their jobs, they'll lose the WITB and face a much larger Ontario Health Levy.

Comment: We are entering the era of robotic space telescope observatories. Here is one inescapable fact about gigantic ground-based optical observatories. By definition, they are only 50% efficient -- they can only operate at night. That efficiency is reduced even more by non-viewing days. Robotic space telescope observatories operate 365/24/7 and view quadrants of the sky, not single targets through a 30-meter straw. There is only one Mauna Kea, space telescope observatories can be built anywhere, and will be. TMT isn't a good investment for Hawaii island. It will be like the rail in Honolulu. TMT is estimated to take 8 to 10 years construction and assembly. Only the construction will be local contractors, assembly will be with off-island professional crews. It will take 2 years to first light, so possibly 12 years before TMT hiring. By then, it will be possible to have space telescopes with apertures of miles, instead of meters. The gigantic ground base optical observatory is on the way out.

Comment: Jesus chose some men for the role of 'apostles.'  No mention of Jesus making priests.  The 12 and the 70 (or 72) were both appointed for the same mission, same Greek verb appointed.  You can see some of the 70 are present at the Last Supper (compare Luke 22:35 and Luke 10:1-4). The key is who is without "purse, bag, sandals." It is the 70. For the 12, it is a different set of accoutrements. Not likely that among the 70 and among the 120 (Pentecost) and at the Last Supper there were no women and it was strictly a boys club.  The apostle Junia, a woman who was in Christianity before Paul (Romans 16:7), may have been one of the 70 apostles  -- in the Eastern Church the 70 are called apostles.  There were women deacons and women presbyters and women bishops in the early Church.  In the earliest days of the Church there were no priests.  Instead, there was a 'priesthood of all believers' (Revelation and 1Peter).  Jesus said 'do this in memory of me' to all apostles and disciples present.

Didn't they read Keynes ?
At the end of WW11, the US agreed to soak up excess production capacity of the world, as the USD was strong and the US was by far the worlds largest consumer .

Free trade with the EU which is essentially Germany hiding behind the Greek denominated Euro.
Germany makes China's trade surplus look like nickels and dimes.

Comment: Thank you for your fulsome reply, Kieran.

I believe there have been a few places in the US (can't recall any specifics) where offending priests were housed together in a quasi-monastic setting, with severe restraints on their freedom of movement, including requiring specific permission for each and every excursion outside of the confines of their home.
