Comment: Well, it seems to me that Russia failed to alter votes in these 21 states, so it appears that the previous administration DID do something to stop it.

Hacking DNC e-mails (if you look up the websites of the GOP and the Democrats, they are ".org" websites, not ".gov"), and the spreading of false stories on the internet, aren't things specifically targeted at the US Government.  Therefore, there isn't much they can do to stop such things.  I'd even say that it isn't government's job to do so (at least those of us that favor small government think so).

Now, let's look at other things....

1) Who issued sanctions on Russia following the election?  Obama.
2) Who had certain Russians expelled, and seized their compounds?  Obama.
3) Who is looking at lifting or lightening sanctions?  Trump.
4) Who is looking at giving back the Russians their compounds?  Trump.
5) Who wanted the anti-Russia plank of the RNC Platform taken out prior to the GOP convention?  Trump.

Thanks for stopping by.

Comment: That’s an interesting question, HabFan410.  I’m not sure what to make of the reality of micro-aggressions.  Many people seem to think that it is an invented term that serves to promote a culture of victimhood.  Thus, people see the young black man who takes serious offence at a joke alluding to the history of slavery as overreacting.  “It’s just a joke; get over it; don’t be a victim,” people say.  The theory of micro aggression, as I understand it, says that constant exposure to such “jokes” has a cumulative effect on a person’s wellbeing.  Is that a real phenomenon?  I’m not sure.  I haven’t studied the issue.  But I have noted that some of the same people who ridicule the theory of micro aggression in minority groups tend to express sentiments of victimization concerning discussions of “white privilege.”  Many people seem to be saying, “I’m sick of hearing about the evils of racism.  Can we just shut up about it?”  Is that perhaps evidence of the reality of micro aggression?

Comment: Question. 
Serious Question.
When a kingdom "dissolves"  What is the process ?  Do they file papers in some international court ? "Hey, we are done, filing bankruptcy, closing down..."  
Do thy have to file paperwork and merge with another governing entity ? Transfer assets ?  Do they have to notify their population, "Our government does not exist any more, you are now subjects of this other entity or you can join up with anyone else you want."  

Seriously, what is the process to dissolve a kingdom ?
Then, was any of that process ever completed with the "Kingdom" of Hawaii ?
I put Kingdom in quotes because a Kingdom is separate from the physical property it occupies.
There are documented cases right now of nations without those nations having their own physical property. It is called a "Stateless Nation"
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stateless_nation

This is what the Kingdom of Hawaii has been equated to, and in fact is shown in the list on that page.

Comment: The US is encumbered by the inadequacies of a 234-year-old constitution and the difficulty of building consensus in an exceptionally large country deeply divided by regional and class differences. 

These impediments came into sharp focus by the end of the 19th century but the resulting logjams were initially finessed by the emergence of strong Presidential leadership and later by the intervention of the US Supreme Court but now the congressional system is in full gridlock with little prospect of a solution.

Into this institutional paralysis and vacuum since the 1970s has stepped the entertainment industry which goads the system to address pressing issues through irony (the reaction of the outsider) and nihilism (the reaction of the enraged).  

Samantha Bee offers a more useful goad: honest anger. However, matters are in a sad state when politics needs to look to its comedians for leadership.

Comment: Since there are several other pipelines in the same area and any sacred sites have already been accounted for and dealt with properly, that argument is a non-starter. I have already explained about the Treaty of 1868 and the fact that the northern border of the reservation is well south of the pipeline. The Sioux Nation accepted the terms of that Treaty and the borders of the reservation. An executive order moved the border north to the Cannon Ball River from the 46th parallel in 1873. The illegal Treaty of 1877 did not change the northern border and it remains at Cannon Ball River, still south of the pipeline location. Facts are such pesky things, aren't they.

Comment: It's called the "!20 day rule", a defendant must be tried within 120 days of being served the criminal complaint.  That's not a lot of time for certain investigations by law enforcement, especially when that period also includes time for the Prosecutor to prepare for trial.  Many times it's better to delay charges to enable you to present a rock solid case because the US justice system is not designed to take every case to trial and therefore Prosecutors actively look for "weak" cases to either kill, or offer a very weak plea bargin on so the defendant will plead out early.

Further, how dumb do you have to be to ignore demographics?

Edmonton falls to pieces most mornings after only a few cms of snow, and even without it, cars warming-up spew lots of water on roads that commonly refreezes in the core winter months each morning. Snow tires ought to be mandatory (as in Quebec) to ensure greater safety and long commuting delays when the latest dusting sends people into the ditches.  And if the provinces won't, insurance companies could still happily raise their rates for those drivers who chose not to buy snow tires. Safety shouldn't be an option.

Comment: "It was hunting season on the refuge."

That is not at all true.   The areas all around the Refuge headquarters and visitor center are either strictly off limits to hunting, or are limited to bird hunting with non-toxic birdshot during seasons.   However, due to the low water level in Malheur Lake this year, the North and South Malheur Lake Waterfowl Units were closed for this past waterfowl season.   So no hunting in the area would have been legal during the occupation.

Besides, Finicum specifically invited hunters to come onto the refuge and hunt Coyotes, which is illegal.

You should check your facts, before making false statements like this.

http://www.fws.gov/refuge/malheur/visit/visitor_activities/hunting.html

Comment: Yes taught well...my problem with many of these conversations is that we can focus on the fact that Algebra isn't the problem so much as the structural fact that while most of us learn things in context, math class doesn't always connect with the application of what we are learning...algebra shows up in all sorts of interesting places...lots of science, chemistry for example, uses algebra. Comment: Dear Alex

In trying to explain some pretty technical stuff, you missed a couple key points relevant to why or why not CO2 removal is important in the case of North Slope pipelines and LNG plants.

1)  The producers should want to capture and reinject the CO2 as part of their Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR) project.  CO2 will significantly increase the oil recovery and that additional oil should payout the CO2 processing cost.

2) CO2 is a real problem at an LNG plant - solid dry ice doesn't go through the gas compressors very well.  CO2 in a gas pipeline just uses up space, but regardless, the specification on allowable CO2 content in pipeline gas is much higher than for gas to an LNG plant.

You need to find a friendly petroleum engineer to fact check these kind of stories before they get printed in the paper.  Reasons companies do or don't spend billions of dollars are multiple and subtle.

Comment: I agree completely. The schools in Oregon have never had stable and predictable support. And the bad budget years do harm that takes years to overcome. Measure 97 is the only plan on the table to stabilize Oregon's wreck of a tax structure. With the deficit we face, it's the only positive and constructive action available. There are other matters, too.  Our infrastructure needs funding, and the quality of technical expertise in our state agencies needs serious attention--we need new new hiring of smarter and better trained people. When you also consider that immigration from other states is at very high levels, you can see that we need to plan for population growth, and that affects all state services and agencies. We need to have a tax structure in place that ensures that newcomers pay their way and don't simply perch on what has already been built here by others. Measure 97 is a solid and effective way to go forward. Doing nothing is not.

Comment: Unfortunately, you chose an elderly patient who spoke no English as an example. This enabled many to sidetrack the "elderly terminal health care issue" to the "elderly family reunification immigration issue". 

I have faced the issue of looking after terminally ill relatives twice. The first time, my mother wished to die at home. So, my brother, brother-in-law and I made arrangements to become "night nurses" sharing the rotation 7 nights a week supplemented by "home care" visits from an Ontario paid health worker from 9:30 am to 4:30 pm each week day for her final 5 weeks. It was a strain; but one that was special as mom and I shared many memories of the family.

The second time was caring for my mother's 97 year old, very frail, cousin. She, too, wished to end her days in her own home. She eventually required re-hospitalization due to acute infection and died there. Family can do a lot; but not everything.

More discussion of solutions "fair" to hospitals / families are warranted.

Comment: S P R I N G
                         by Mary Oliver ©

Somewhere
   a black bear
         has just risen from sleep
              and is staring

down the mountain.
    All night
         in the brisk and shallow restlessness
             of early spring

I think of her,
     her four black fists
          flicking the gravel,
                her tongue

like a red fire
   touching the grass,
        the cold water.
            There is only one question:

how to love this world.
      I think of her
           rising
               like a bland and leafy ledge

to sharpen her claws against
      the silence
          of the trees.
               Whatever else

my life is
    with its poems
          and its music
               and its glass cities,

it is also this dazzling darkness
   coming
         down the mountain
                breathing and tasting;

all day I think of her –
     her white teeth,
          her wordlessness,
                 her perfect love.

A free market system would say that if people cared about recycling, they'd only buy products easy to recycle (or biodegradable), and corporations would oblige with such products.  Why don't we let market forces work?

Comment: What cannot be grown must be mined. Look around the space you're sitting in and ask yourself where your "stuff" came from. The computer you're using, for example. Oil, hundreds of different minerals, electricity provided by diesel, coal or natural gas.

Mining makes our modern world possible. It provides good-paying long-term jobs. And it can be done in an environmentally-sensitive way.

But you're rather not risk it, so -- well, just start subtracting the stuff around you that comes from mining. Does your modern lifestyle still exist? You no longer have a refrigerator, but if you did, you'd notice that there's no food in it, because that modern food you eat requires fertilizer which is mined and fuel to transport it to you, which is mined.

Pretty soon you're starving in the dark with no stuff to keep you warm.

Remember, what cannot be grown must be mined and even fishing depends on mining.

Comment: The sad truth is that the current human activity contribution to greenhouse gas emission is significantly increasing the pace of climate change beyond that which natural causes would induce.  It follows that, while the excessive extremes of the Leap Agenda are to be avoided, moderate measures to reduce the human carbon footprint need to be pursued.  Canada's contribution to this effort is to show that significant progress can be made to curtail such emissions by a large, advanced and modern society without imploding its economy.

This is a major challenge but it's doable by Canada and a well-designed revenue neutral (i.e. revenue rebated to residents) carbon tax with a legislated schedule of periodic tax rate increases is a keystone public policy initiative in achieving this goal.

The fact that the US plans to join Saudi Arabia in pretending that such emissions are acceptable should not and need not deter us (or unduly put our fossil fuel development as a disadvantage).

Ryan promised that when the Republicans replace the ACA, no-one, not one American, will be worse off than under the ACA. He was lying.
I don’t know how many people voted for Trump because they believed his promises about health care, but those who did ought to insist that he propose a health care plan that reflects those promises.

Comment: I have no idea which of the aircraft on offer, if any, would meet Canada's long term air defence needs. That's probably true for most Canadians. It is an inherently complex logistical, technical, economic exercise. 

Which is why - given the billions at stake - Canada's independent oversight agencies should be front and centre in the debate. And, indeed, the PBO and the AG did wade in several years ago on Harper's plan to buy the F35s. They warned government had grossly - quite deliberately no doubt - understated the total cost of ownership. 

I dismiss half the comments here either because they come from rabid anti-Trudeau-ites, or because they have some other axe to grind. Nor can I put much stock in what the authors have to say because the article comes with no declaration they are free of conflicts. 

I'm not convinced government is on the right track here but I'm keeping an open mind until I hear from someone I can trust as authoritative, insightful and independent.

Comment: This is excellent. Really! 

I regard the First Nations of Canada as our National Treasure.  When I first read the writings of Archibald Belaney known to history as Grey Owl, I wanted to be an Indian.  My parents were not prejudiced against anyone. They taught that racism is a false god.  When I was in my late twenties, I had the chance to live for a year on the Six Nations of the Grand River.  Because I respected the people, I was treated accordingly. One night while on the way to a dance off the Reserve, I asked the driver if only Indians would be there. He replied, "You're an Indian, sort of."  Nice!

Canada's treatment of the First Nations sanctioned by the government under the aegis of Christian clergy unleashed a legacy of racial terror upon children of the First Nations.  Only when Canadians en mass come to terms with this blight upon our historical pass, will Canada attain its high destiny.  Drew Hayden Taylor's article is a reminder how far we have to go.  

All my relations

Comment: You've missed my point. I wasn't commenting on cases where there is a quality difference between the two results. The point I was making only holds for studies that are of equal quality.

In cases where the is a clear result, then the majority of high quality studies will have that result. In cases where there are multiple high quality studies that provide a mixed result overall, the effect being studied is likely to be rather minor.

Comment: I met Jim in 1980, when he and Bonny sheltered me at their home while  recovering from a world class case of giardia, with the docs at Providence saying I needed appendectomy. For the record, I still have my appendix, but more than that a great memory of one evening when Bonny went out with her girlfriends and Jim left the house to quaff a few with his buddies. I'd spoken with him about an idea I had for a starting weekly newspaper in Bristol Bay, which elicited little more comment from Jim beyond "hmm, interesting." Until late that evening, when Jim came home to see me still scribbling at the far end of the dining room table. "So you want to start a newspaper, eh?" he said. "I used to do some of that kind of work." And taking his weighty Pulitzer medal from the mantel, he bounced it across the long wooden table and squarely into my chest. "Some people said I was pretty good at it!" This J-School dropout was impressed. Pulitzers are heavy! R.I.P. Jim. Fritz Johnson, Bristol BayTimes

Comment: Here is some fact checking vs your cherry picking:

http://www.msn.com/en-us/news/factcheck/in-gorsuch-confirmation-battle-both-sides-spin-and-mislead/ar-BBzhKJN

Key items:

It takes only a majority, 51 votes, to confirm a nominee. Two current Supreme Court justices, Samuel A. Alito Jr. and Clarence Thomas, did not receive 60 confirmation votes.

But under current Senate rules, ending debate or a filibuster over a Supreme Court nominee — called a cloture vote — requires a three-fifths majority. Eight Democrats would need to vote for cloture to end debate over Judge Gorsuch and bring his nomination to a straight up-down vote.

The Senate has moved to invoke cloture only four times for Supreme Court nominations in history, most recently in 2006 for Justice Alito’s confirmation when it voted 72-25 to end debate.

Mr. Schumer is right that the most successful nominees have met the 60-vote bar at some point. Justice Thomas is the one exception since 1949.

It's also a position that many QB's take advantage of for check downs and progression of reads as the tight end is often the third or even fourth read in a QB's progression. Comment: "Why is the Second Amendment the only amendment that can admit of no restrictions? Maybe I should be able to yell fire in a crowded theater to protect all my rights."

1st of all, you error in thinking that a majority of the gun rights movement think that the 2nd Amendment right is unlimited.  Witness the NRA on machine guns and bump stocks.  Ditto for the NRA support of the current background check system.

Second, have you actually read the landmark Heller (2008) decision and the follow on McDonald (2010) decision?  This is what you will find:

1) Firearms "in common civilian use" are protected.  If the people choose to own a type of firearm in significant numbers, it's protected.  Handguns, the #1 murder weapon, were the subject of this decision.
2) Weapons not in common use, are not protected.
3) In order to be banned, a weapon must be both unusual and dangerous.

Since this ruling, most courts have simply ruled as if it did not exist - but other have used it to expand gun rights

Comment: Anthony Westell was one of my professors, but he had taught me well before that, with his writing at The Star and The Globe and Mail.  I challenged him on journalists inserting themselves into stories, and he told me he had learned that journalism was about attribution. The journalist doesn't ever know what someone 'believes' so never use that attribution. Nor does a journalist know what anyone 'thinks'. He/she only knows 'what they say they believe or think' so that is the only proper way to describe their words. You can report that the person 'appeared sorrowful, with tears running down his cheeks' but saying the person was sorrowful is beyond a reporter's skill level. He told me he had learned these lessons by doing it wrong, and reflecting. He made me reflect. He was right, and I don't know how he'd react to the egregious editorializing in print and on TV, as just now on The National, and its presentation as fact, but I can imagine. He was a great man. RIP. Quote me on that.

Comment: I have lived in Quebec for most of my life. I agree with the author. It's shameful and unconscionable how pets, livestock (e.g., those enormous pig farms), and wild animals are treated. It's as if we're all stuck in 1750, when life was extremely hard for people, but the forests extended from horizon to horizon, and the waters teemed with fish. We're not in that world anymore!
My few years in Ontario were quite different, vis à vis cultural attitudes towards animals.  
I have to admit I stay here because the benefits outweigh the costs. But I do whatever I can to alert people to the loss of green spaces, the poor treatment of companion animals, and the cruelty of industrial agriculture (all of which exist outside of Quebec, of course).

Comment: This story misses the mark. The CBA pilot projects and their results actually tell a powerful story of shared accountability and great success on equity outcomes (www.portlandcbapilotprojects.com).  Any implication of wrong doing by CBA partners is false. The CBA oversight committee proactively developed CBA fund strategies, City staff served on the CBA oversight committee and RFP review committees, RFPs were publicly disseminated to solicit proposals, and CBA partners who submitted proposals did not serve on related RFP review committees nor vote on funding decisions.  The real questions: Why did the City provide so little guidance to partners regarding CBA funds? If the City had concerns, why did City staff fail to raise these concerns over three years as part of the CBA oversight committee?  Why are City staff now choosing to focus on unsubstantiated "perceived" conflicts as opposed to actual CBA project outcomes and activities?

Comment: There are two ways to understand the concept of hypocrisy. One is to equate it to the idea of "do as I say, not as I do". The other, used by dictionaries, is that it is a pretense, a gap between what one thinks and what one states.

The first is childish. Ex: The fat doctor is unqualified to give health advice, a clueless opinion-writer's past residence in another state taints any useful advice he might have, and public assembly is inherently un-American.

The second is concerned with motives, not actions: where the thought and the expression don't match. A fat doctor is still a doctor; a Southerner isn't an idiot solely because he's a Southerner; public assembly is not always a precursor to torches and/or lynching.

True hypocrisy is hitting people for being chimerical - while espousing outright lies formed of inadequate review.

(I'd also point out that "running off to be a Rhodes Scholar" doesn't really sound like an indictment at all. Sure beats the circus.)

Comment: Foreign investors fuel the housing market.  They raise property values which raise property taxes for municipalities. Higher values benefit the majority of society because 75% of the population own their primary residence.  Higher values lead to more local spending on local goods and services.  More consumption and home equity can be used for more domestic investment in local businesses.  Some foreign investors generate income tax on Canadian income as well. 

And investment in the local property market fuels employment in construction, marketing and advertising, legal, engineering, finance, brokerage, furniture, insurance, etc. 

And foreign investors send their children to local private schools that pay teachers salaries and of course other operating expenses. 

Foreign investors fuel demand for hotel rooms, car rentals and purchases, etc. 

Remove foreign investment from Vancouver and you'll probably find yourself out of a job.

Comment: I'm curious why you are using only 46 weeks/year?  Last I checked there were 52 weeks in the year and someone working full-time, even for minimum wage, would receive 2 weeks paid vacation (either directly paid or via 4% "vacation pay") plus paid holidays.

So what are the 6 weeks of unpaid work for?

So if we look at 52 weeks and 35 hours at the current minimum wage of $11.40/hour we get $20,748/year.  Add in the various government benefits (HST credits,  energy and property tax credits, etc. ) and we're already above your "poverty line".

One point of note though, Canada does not have a defined "poverty line".  There are several unofficial measures of what might constitute a "poverty line", though the exact definition of it would be very arbitrary.

Comment: The Pope is gonna be critiqued by many for not going far enough in his actions and I can see where people making these criticisms are coming from. However given the scale of the problem, the scale of the mess he has inherited, combined with the entrenched resistance to his reforms he is facing, on the whole I would say Francis is doing a good job trying his mightiest to address this. 

The fact that he wrote a preface to a book written by a sex abuse victim on this topic is pretty amazing. The fact that he has set up tribunals and is the first Pope to have prosecutions of abusers(such as the case involving priests from El Salvador) is also pretty historic given that every Pope before him going back to John XXIII failed to do so. 

So even though people may not like the pace of how this are going, the Pope in his own way is making changes slowly and incrementally that in the long run in the future, will seem substantial.

Comment: Whatever system is put into place it will ultimately depend on "peer review" for evaluation of grants. The basic problem with the present system is that Canada is simply not big enough for effective, impartial peer reviews. The reviewers are either not sufficiently familiar with the reviewed topics, or are too close to the researchers, good or bad. In my career I've had massive grants from reviews by people in the same topic who thought it was the answer to everything; outright rejection from reviewers working in different fields who thought the ideas worthless  - all for the same topic area. I've also served on enough review committees to know what a disorganised jungle the review system is.- millions of $ depending on someone's spur of the moment likes or dislikes. Unless we solve this basic problem, any federal granting system will be a crap shoot.

Comment: Thanks for this, Elton. The study you linked to provides a pretty good overview of factors affecting voter turnout. Among the factors which may help explain Hawaii's low turnout is the absence of competitive races, with the presidential race at the top, but also in down-ticket races.

Nonetheless, Hawaii has a very low turnout rate. We also are the only state with zero members of the minority party in one of our chambers. Our elections are not competitive. Few people want to vote for Republicans. Voters prefer Democrats, yet that does not produce laws which deliver on the Democratic platform's commitment to working and middle class voters. Comment: BTW - what makes you think I have an antipathy to development?  I’m only opposed to bad development – the definition of which of course is the subject of another conversation. 

For illustration: I opposed the Ho‘opili development, even though three quarters of it will be TOD, because it is being built on top of the most productive food-growing farmland in the state – a classic example of planning malpractice.  I did not want the development stopped; I wanted it relocated to downtown Kapolei. 

After two years making a documentary about homelessness, I am acutely aware of the desperate need for housing and I am constantly urging our elected representatives to find ways to help private developers build tens of thousands of new homes to address this affordable housing crisis.  I’m all for it so long as the homes are built for locals and go into areas that are already urbanized: Mo‘ili‘ili, McCully, Iwilei, Kalihi, Waipahu…

Finally, the carbon tax I support would be revenue-neutral.

Comment: The biggest difference I saw was there was no obsession with political leadership at all.   The head of the country rotated every couple of years or so.  Power was spread around.   The Swiss simply weren't terribly interested in domestic politics.

People expected their elected officials and the public service to run the country well.    That was non-negotiable.  The plebiscites were often poorly attended -- most Swiss viewed it as a responsibility to vote in plebiscites at least some of the time,...but not always.    Plebiscite turnouts when I was there were typically around 30- 35%.

It is true that it is a much smaller country geographically and so a lot of the biggest challenges Canada vis-a-vis logistics related to size are not relevant there.   However, in terms of population, it's about 25% of the size of Canada,...so it's not tiny.   It was striking how different the culture was in comparison to, say, Italy, France or even Austria and Germany.

Comment: Rubbish.  The entire surface area of the reservoir is 4,000 Ha, or 40 square kilometres, (20 Km  x 2 Km.) That's roughly double the surface area of the river at present. The area to be flooded represents 0.4% of Ag land in the Peace River district and 0.2% of Ag land in BC.  If that will feed 1 million, the balance of Peace River Ag land can feed almost 140 million Canadians. 

Alternative energy sources? A  windmill has a 20 year lifespan. A dam's electrical generation capacity is approximately 100 years.  The Paris accord requires CO2 cuts of 30% by 2030, the transportation sector which contributes 27% of CO at present, must be electrified. The claim that we can rely on the Columbia River (USA) dam's capacity is foolish. When Trump says America First, it means everyone else last. The only energy security we can count on is our domestic supply.

Finally, blowing off about $5 billion to mothball a $9  or $10 billion project is astoundingly stupid.
